title: Allow packages to configure browserify via their `package.json` file
body:
Considering https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/407#issuecomment-30394491 and https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/240#issuecomment-30393906 it seems the use case https://github.com/jesusabdullah/browserify-cdn/issues/54 is bust

Thinking about this, what about offering package authors the ability to customise the way browserify builds themselves via a `browserify` field in their `package.json` file. So for caterpillar, I could add this to the `package.json` file:

```
"browserify": {
  "ignore": ['readable-stream']
}
```

title: use real paths to allow symlinks without dupes
body:
Allow the use of symlinks in your browserified project.

e.g., `npm link` or `npm install --link`

Fixes issue #444.

title: Bundle Graph
body:
I've seen the dependency graph, but I was wondering if it is possible to do something like the following example.
- In my final project, I will have the need for 3 entry points scripts.
- I can specify multiple entry points, and will be given the shared runtime scripts needed, or they can be automatically generated.

Something like this (Please understand this is to just to demonstrate the concept):

``` shell
$ browserify --bundle-graph-list -e main.js -e worker1.js -e worker2.js

Runtime Entry Points:
main.js
├─ uniquefoo.js
├─ uniquemoduledep1.js
worker1.js
├─ uniquefoo.js
├─ uniquebar.js
│ ├─ uniquebaz.js
├─ uniquemoduledep2.js
worker2.js
├─ uniquebaz.js
├─ uniquemoduledep3.js

Recommended Common Runtime Bundles:
shared/bundle1.js
├─ uniquefoo.js
shared/bundle2.js
├─ uniquebar.js
│ ├─ uniquebaz.js
```

Maybe something to show the recommended command(s):

``` shell
$ browserify --bundle-graph-cmd -e main.js -e worker1.js -e worker2.js

browserify -r uniquefoo.js > static/shared/bundle1.js
browserify -r uniquebaz.js -r uniquebar.js > static/shared/bundle2.js
browserify -x uniquefoo.js main.js > static/main.js
browserify -x uniquefoo.js -x uniquebar.js -x uniquebaz.js worker1.js > static/worker1.js
browserify -x uniquebar.js -x uniquebaz.js worker2.js > static/worker2.js
```

Or maybe just do it:

``` shell
$ browserify --bundle-graph-build -e main.js -e worker1.js -e worker2.js

Created 5 bundles, 3 entries, 2 shared
```

Final build would look like:
- **static/main.js** -> bundled: _src/uniquemoduledep1.js_
- **static/worker1.js** -> bundled: _src/uniquemoduledep2.js_
- **static/worker2.js** -> bundled: _src/uniquemoduledep3.js_
- **static/shared/bundle1.js** -> bundled: _src/uniquefoo.js_
- **static/shared/bundle2.js** -> bundled: _src/uniquebar.js, src/uniquebaz.js_

index.html:

``` html
<script src="shared/bundle1.js"></script>
<script src="shared/bundle2.js"></script>
<script src="main.js"></script>
```

worker1.js:

``` javascript
importScripts('shared/bundle1.js');
importScripts('shared/bundle2.js');
```

worker2.js:

``` javascript
importScripts('shared/bundle2.js');
```

The idea is to have something that understands multiple application runtime entry points, that can give you the recommended commonly shared scripts among them that need to be bundled. The previous example may be a bad one, but I hope you can understand what I'm trying to explain.

If something like this is already possible, would love to see an example!

Thanks.

title: allow -x to pass on the expose option
body:
Similar to how you can use -r ./module-file.js:module-name to set the
exposed require name for a module, we should be able to set the exposed
module name for external modules.

This allows the user to require vendor libraries into a bundle using
short names, and to allow access to those libraries using the short
name.

An example using jquery installed with bower might look like:

browserify -r ./bower_components/jquery/jquery.js:jquery -o vendor.js
browserify -x ./bower_components/jquery/jquery.js:jquery app.js

title: Added cacheify to the list of known transforms in the README
body:
I'm not sure what the requirements are to get a place on the README so I figured I'd put it out there anyway. 

This transform is sadly incompatible with the command line usage, but I find it extremely helpful in projects with api-based bundling and I have lots of sometimes expensive transforms running behind a watch task.

title: folderify transform
body:
Added [folderify](https://github.com/parroit/folderify) to tranforms.

Folderify inline a whole directory content in browserify results.
1. It uses falafel to intercepts calls to [include-folder](https://github.com/parroit/include-folder) 
2. use include-folder to generate source code of a function with a fs.readFileSync call for each file in directory
3. feed brfs stream with generated source code 
4. replace include-folder call with brfs output

title: Use `native-buffer-browserify` for fast Buffer (backed by ArrayBuffer)
body:
Sending this over to add `native-buffer-browserify` and show how to fix the test failures on node 0.10 because of a bug in the `vm` module where it doesn't make `Uint8Array` available in the execution context. This appears to be fixed in Node 0.11.

(These changes might need to be moved into the 3.0 branch which @substack said he'll push tonight)

command line cannot use custom transform module
adding browserify-shim to transforms
body: browserify-shim v3 is a pure transform now and can be completely configured inside the package.json, unlike v2.

title: Re-ordered bundle() callback fixing to before pending check
body:
cb358b265441b088a232e3bf581601af5e74582e added a fix for potential double callbacks, but it didn't quite catch the case where a bundle was pending because that makes a recursive call with the un-fixed `cb`, and so some cases were still calling back more than once.

Moving the callback fix to before the point at which the code branched for pending bundles fixes this.

title: --standalone A.B.C should construct nested objects.
body:
Given the following set of options:

```
browserify index.js --standalone A.B.C
```

One would expect the generated UMD snippet to preserve the nested object relationship, such that:

``` js
((ref$ = (window.A || window.A = {}).B) || ref$.B = {}).C = entryPoint()
```

title: Client-side require() needs improvement
body:
Client-side require was working brilliantly in Browserify v1 but appears to be lacking in v2 (and is desperately needed). Basically, I need to be able to require() a bundle's sub-modules from outside the bundle on the client-side.

In v1, Browserify could optionally expose a global require() function on the client side which let you do exactly that. The require function also exposed a really nice require.modules property which allowed me to check whether a module was already contained inside my bundle - That way if the user tried to load a module dynamically at runtime but it was already present inside the bundle, then I would just use the one in the bundle instead of having to load it again.

Another feature that is desperately needed in v2 is to be able to expose ALL sub modules in a bundle to be available via client-side require() - At present it seems that there is no simple way to do that because I don't know what modules will be bundled-in before it actually happens - By which point it is too late to call bundle.require().

If having a global require() function is not desirable; at least expose a myBundle.require() function on the client when the standalone property is specified.

title: `this` should be `module.exports`/`exports` like in Node.
body:
Instead it is the window in sloppy mode/nothing in strict mode.

Some modules, like the popular Sinon.JS library, cannot be browserified because of this.

title: Lack of support for shorthand require notation
body:
I'm using

```
require './my_util'
```

in my CoffeeScript files, while Browserify can't handle that. Changing it to:

```
require './my_util.coffee'
```

solves the problem, but I'd expect that Browserify supports this syntax as well.

title: Addition of compile-time flags?
body:
Hey,

I'm writing a couple of apps that share a hell of a lot of code between server and browser. Right down to how it loads the template, where it switches to jQuery instead of using the node fs module.

Just wondering if anybody else has had the need to cut out code that's unnecessary for the browser? If so I'll look at making a fork, otherwise I can just implement this as part of my middleware.

Cheers
G

title: Standard source-map comments like `//# sourceMappingURL` are ignored
body:
As it turnes out browserify does not attempts to combine sourcemaps if source has it's
maps specified via `//# sourceMappingURL` rather that `//@ sourceMappingURL`. Note that former is a standard according to latest spec & firefox will complain if `@` is used instead of `#`. Actual example can be found under #528

title: bundling source-map-ed files spits out broken source maps
body:
Here is an example code:
https://gist.github.com/Gozala/7522960

Modules `foo.js`, `bar.js` and `main.js` are spit out by "to js" compiler and  have source-maps that can be parsed and all browsers seem to handle fine.

When `main.js` is browseryfied to a `bundle.js` produced source-map seems broken.

title: minor readme help syntax fix
Provide the ability to build AMD modules with browserify
body: I'm actually a little unclear about this. Does browserify have the ability to create AMD modules from commonjs modules? If not, I think it would be very useful feature to add. I actually built a library to do that: https://github.com/fresheneesz/buildModules , but it'd be much better if a more supported project like browserify would do it - since the purposes overlap so much.

title: --standalone incompatible with --external and with browserify
body:
Hi,

I wanted to use `--standalone` as a way to "compile" my (multi-files) library to one bundle file, however it doesn't work as I expected with (1) **browserify** and (2) `--external`:
- If you use your bundle.js back in Browserify (as a `require('mylib')`), it will break on the first `require('./some/thing')` of the library because the new browserify will parse again all the require of the bundle (the browserified bundle contains a lot of call to contextual call to require). A workaround for that is using noparse but this is not the purpose of noparse and it won't work when requiring externals.
- AFAIK `--standalone` is impossible to work with `--external` due to the previous point. Also there is no way, if using the bundle library in a `<script>`, to say where to take the library (e.g. `require('q')` should be resolve by `window.Q`).

**Am I doing something wrong (against the philosophy?) or is it a limitation?**

Any idea to solve that? For me it seems the way `require` call are parsed is not scope aware at all (it's just a grep, not an AST parsing). if a require is locally defined, browserify won't see it.
A hacky workaround would be that `require` function variables could be renamed in the bundle and only the externals could be kept as `require`.

title: Added phantomjsify to README
body:
I have created a `browserify` transform that shims node.js core for PhantomJS. This PR adds `phantomjsify` to the list of transforms.

https://github.com/twolfson/phantomjsify

title: Incorrect "Missing module" error handling
body:
Inside `_resolve`, the external function call `browserResolve` has a callback that is treating missing modules the same as "general" errors - rather than falling through to the specific "module X not found from Y" handler. It is also not honoring the `--ignoreMissing` option for the same reason.

The underlying cause is that `async.js` inside of package `browser-resolve` is using `new Error("Cannot find module...")` as the `err` callback parameter when a module is not found - but Browserify expects no error, just an empty `file` parameter.

Because there is no way to tell the difference between a real error, and a "module not found" error - I can't think of a nice and easy way to fix the problem: it seems like it would take some agreement between Async, Browser-resolve, and Browserify. So I have opened this issue.

(Additionally, I found this bug while trying to add the full filename of the file which tried to require a missing module... which would also be nice to have.)

title: Browserify 2.35.2 raise 404
Ensure source maps are the last line
body: Failing test and a simple fix.

title: 390 standalone debug redux
body:
A simpler approach to fixing an off-by-one error in generated source map line numbers when using --standalone and --debug.

Simply prevent the UMD prelude from affecting the line numbers by trimming it.

Test case included.

title: Q (promises library) refuses to be browserified
selective bundling times
body:
Given this entry file:

``` js
require('through');
require('util');

console.log('hi');
```

the normal bundling time is:

``` bash
$ time browserify test.js > /dev/null

real    0m0.698s
user    0m0.752s
sys 0m0.067s
```

Is it me or is that slow for such a small dependency tree?

Trying to shorten bundling times, I split up my bundle and first try removing node_modules:

``` bash
$ time browserify -x through test.js > /dev/null

real    0m0.306s
user    0m0.288s
sys 0m0.043s
```

Ok, that's already 50% faster. But, when splitting up your bundle, you wouldn't want to have node's `util` module in both your app and your deps bundle, so we remove that too:

``` bash
$ time browserify -x through -x util test.js > /dev/null

real    0m0.272s
user    0m0.240s
sys 0m0.039s
```

Ok, even better. But we still have a problem: the build command needs to be adjusted whenever you add or remove a dependency, and this will become rather messy, especially for large apps, where this technique matters.

So I tried programmatically reading required node_modules and builtins and telling browserify to externalize them:

``` js
var through = require('through');
var browserify = require('browserify');

var b = browserify(__dirname + '/test.js');
b.deps().pipe(through(write, end));

function write(dep) {
  var m = /browser-builtins\/builtin\/(.*).js/.exec(dep.id)
    || /node_modules\/([^\/]+)/.exec(dep.id);
  if (m) b.external(m[1]);
}

function end() {
  b.bundle() // ...
}
```

Doing it this way, build times are worse again:

``` bash
$ time node selective.js test.js > /dev/null

real    0m0.629s
user    0m0.644s
sys 0m0.076s
```

I assume this is because I'm reading the dependency graph twice: Once at `b.deps()` and once at `b.bundle()`. Is that correct?

Assuming it is, i should rather pipe my filtered version of `b.deps()` into a writable browserify stream that does the rest.

Currently I'd have to recreate all the logic from https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L217-L242. Should browserify be able to take a custom deps stream?

title: Bundle hash changes depending on directory with --require
body:
I am building a browserify bundle which exports some modules to be used from code in the browser.  The bundle has a version-specific name derived from the hash of the bundle.

This doesn't work when using -r because the absolute name of the input file is hashed to make an export.  Since the absolute name will include each developer's username in the path, it means that the build has to be done exactly the same by every user on every machine in order to produce a file which hashes the same.

If I apply `replace(process.cwd(), '')` to the parameter of `hash` on the following lines then the problem is worked around:
- https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L293
- https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L114

This is a bit hacky so I didn't make a pull request.  I think that making the hashed paths relative to the basedir would be the best way.  I'm not sure I understand enough how to do this but if you could give me some pointers or maybe test cases I could have a go at it.

This issue means I can't use already existing grunt modules ([example](http://davidtucker.net/articles/automating-with-grunt/)) to build the bundles, however writing it in rake would make the whole thing much easier anyway.

Additionally #355 might make what I want to do impossible (although it appears to works fine for me).

The workaround I will use is to generate the version-specific name from a hash of the input files instead (from --deps) which is a bit less neat but would achieve more or less the same thing.

Therefore I would say this isn't particularly critical to solve, but if you did decide to make repeatable builds a feature then I think solving this would be necessary in addition to #355.

title: require doesnt work with string references, only literals?
Transform modules and required files in node_modules
body:
I encountered some issues with coffeeify. It seems like .coffee files that are require()d from node_modules are treated as JavaScript files, probably meaning that coffeeify isn't transforming them prior to being parsed.

Here's how to reproduce it (from a previous issue at [coffeeify/#7](https://github.com/jnordberg/coffeeify/issues/7)):

``` bash
$ npm init && npm install coffeeify browserify
...

$ echo 'console.log "Hello"' > node_modules/b.coffee

# Not working when require()d from node_modules:
$ echo 'require "./node_modules/b.coffee"' > a.coffee
$ browserify -t coffeeify a.coffee

/tmp/browserify-test/node_modules/b.coffee:1
console.log "Hello"
            ^
ParseError: Unexpected string

# Works with other directories:
$ ln -s node_modules not_node_modules
$ echo 'require "./not_node_modules/b.coffee"' > a.coffee
$ browserify -t coffeeify a.coffee

;(function e(t,n,r){function s(o,u){if(!n[o]){if(!t[o]){var a=typeof require=="function"&&require;if(!u&&a)return a(o,!0);if(i)return i(o,!0);throw new Error("Cannot find module '"+o+"'")}var f=n[o]={exports:{}};t[o][0].call(f.exports,function(e){var n=t[o][1][e];return s(n?n:e)},f,f.exports,e,t,n,r)}return n[o].exports}var i=typeof require=="function"&&require;for(var o=0;o<r.length;o++)s(r[o]);return s})({1:[function(require,module,exports){
require("./not_node_modules/b.coffee");


},{"./not_node_modules/b.coffee":2}],2:[function(require,module,exports){
console.log("Hello");


},{}]},{},[1])

```

title: Having "require" to check if a module is declared on "window"
duplicate core modules in bundle output
body:
I noticed that when creating a bundle, buffer-browserify (including Buffer, readIEEE754, base64-js), assert, util, and the browser shims are being included in the output twice.

However, when looking at the output of --deps they only show up once.

title: Indicate nomap
body:
fixes: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/497
- currently browser-pack overwrites sourcemapped code with the redirect code
- flagging deduped rows as such allows browser-pack to keep sourcemaps for original code instead
- the `nomap` flag is respected once [this PR](https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/pull/24) is merged

title: Provide browser-specific shim for domain
Alias (= require with expose option) include the file alias file in bundle in anycase
body:
Following #290,  "aliasing" a module can be done with:

``` js
b.require(__dirname + '/client-side-fs.js', { expose: 'fs' });
b.add('entry.js')
```

That makes the file `/client-side-fs.js` be bundled and used as `fs`.

However, wether `entry.js` (or dependencies) uses `fs` or not, `/client-side-fs.js` gets bundled in any case.

I guess that's an expected behavior. However, is there a way to declare `/client-side-fs.js` as an alias of `fs` and not bundle it if `fs` is not used? Shouldn't be an option?

title: Individual file incorrectly displayed -- sourcemap bug?
body:
When using Chrome to debug concatenated, browserified files, occasionally a file's source in the developer tool displays something like:

``` javascript
module.exports=require('Kl13EO');
```

I am not doing any uglification, etc. so would expect this to show the full source of that file. Is this a Chrome bug, browserify bug, or am I doing something incorrectly?

title: 390 standalone debug
body:
This is to fix #390. I'm not actually sure what OP was reporting as problematic, but the only problems I observe are a problem with source map alignment.

I did something presumptuous and added a package.json bump for substack/browser-pack.

It assumes substack/browser-pack#23 merge, and subsequent version bump.

Tests pass here and in browser-pack.

In my testing, I'm having no issues using these options together with `browserify.bundle()`.

title: Comparison of separate, identical functions is equal, when they should be unequal
substack/coffeeify -> jnordberg/coffeeify
browservfy is deprecated in favor of beefy
Browserifying a single file with noParse does not work
body:
Not sure if this is silly, but I am simply trying to browserify a file (/many files) so
that they can be required client_side. I was trying to does this via combination of

``` javascript
var b = browersify(fileName, {noParse: fileName})
b.require(fileName, {expose: name}
```

However, noParse is NOT respected when the first arg is a string.

---

var b = browserify(files=[] or opts={})

Create a browserify instance b from the entry main files or opts.entries. files can be an array of files or a single file.

You can also specify an opts.noParse array which will skip all require() and global parsing for each file in the array. Use this for giant libs like jquery or threejs that don't have any requires or node-style globals but take forever to parse.

opts.extensions is an array of optional extra extensions for the module lookup machinery to use when the extension has not been specified. By default browserify considers only .js and .json files in such cases.

Note that if files do not contain javascript source code then you also need to specify a corresponding transform for them.

title: Replace backslashes with slashes in sourcemaps paths
body: This fixes the folder display in Chrome/Firefox with Windows style paths

title: update umd version
body: the version of `umd` that is being required throws an error inside a web worker where 'global' isn't always defined.

title: Recursive transforms
body:
No ability to use -t recursively, found this issue with having Backbone.View's referencing their template.hbs files. When all in root directory hbsfy works fine, however when views are listed as depenecies and so in node_modules/modulename/ or  node_modules/modulename/node_module/submodulename this fails. 

How difficult would it be to implement recursive transforms? Can see this being a nice addition

title: Transforms not called when using require
body:
The following command doesn't seem to run the "debowerify" transform module:

```
browserify -t debowerify -r jquery -o bundle.js
```

This results in the error "Cannot find module 'jquery'". The expected result would be that the transform is called and the bower component jquery is bundled.

title: Buffer conflict: Two different implementations provided that won't interoperate
browserify --external aliases the module id of the external module if the module is present
browserify dedupe doesn't play well with source maps
body:
@johnkpaul ran into an issue as follows:

When bundling a file, lets call it `foo.js`, with the same content twice, it is deduped and one just has a redirecting require in it, i.e.:

``` js
module.exports = require('some id here');
```

Unfortunately the content for `foo.js` included in the source maps is not the original content, but the one line redirect instead.

As a result it is impossible to debug the actual code of `foo.js` since opening it up in dev tools just shows the one line redirect instead of the original `foo.js` content.

I'm yet unclear on what exactly is going on, since both file still should have gotten different ids and therefore the sourcemaps should contain multiple `foo.js`s each with different paths.  So we need to investigate further.

Possibly @johnkpaul can provide an isolated test case, otherwise I'll try to repro it.

I'm not sure how this can be fixed, but have three general options how to approach it:
- a) When generating the row, indicate if it just contains a redirect to another file, i.e. `row.redirect = true`. The sourcemap generation in browser-pack can then take that into account.
- b) The sourcemap generation in browser-pack gets smart enough to realize that if we already generated a sourcemap for a file content and the current content is shorter, it is most likely a redirect and should not overwrite the original content.
- c) The sourcemap generation in browser-pack assumes that rows are ordered so that redirects are emitted after the original content. Therefore it will just check in the hash if it already generated sourcemaps for the file and doesn't overwrite it.

title: Trailing semicolon breaks sourcemaps
body:
According to the spec, **source maps urls need to appear on the last line** of the file.
However browserify adds a `;` as the last line of the bundle, I suppose to protect from incorrect code that may follow.

It seems like this will break source maps in future versions of chrome as is apparent in the latest version of Canary - [for more info review this issue](http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=299001#c8)

Therefore we need to not add this semicolon on the last line (at least when `debug === true`.

title: Browserify 2.18.1 requires Git
body: I'd like to run my node-xmpp project on client machines without requiring git.  Tracked down the dependency to browserify 2.18.1.  In version 2.20.1, git is no longer required.  Could you consider upgrading that dependency to avoid requiring git?

title: Very strange issue involving a source file called "dialogs.js"
body:
I just spent several hours tracking down a very strange bug that was related to my having a file named "dialogs.js" in my browserify source files. The bug disappeared after I renamed the file to "mydialogs.js".

The bug consists of a specific custom event (jQuery) that I use in my code no longer reaching its intended listener. It's almost as if there suddenly were two instances of the jQuery object ($), unaware of each other.

I suspect it all may have something to do with the way I'm using jQuery and jQuery UI. Here's are my shims (I'm using grunt-browserify):

```
var browserify_shims = {
    jquery      : { path: './bower_components/jquery/jquery.js', exports: '$' },
    'jquery-ui' : { path: './bower_components/jquery-ui/ui/jquery-ui.js', depends: { jquery: '$' }, exports: null },
    'jade' : { path: './node_modules/jade/lib/jade.js', exports: null }
}
```

(This object is used as the "shim" parameter of the "options" object. The only other option I'm using is "debug": true)

In two of my source modules, including "dialogs.js", I have the following requires:

```
var $ = require('jquery')
require('jquery-ui')
```

This completely baffles me - neither jQuery nor jQuery UI have a file called "dialogs.js" in their trees, and yet simply renaming my module to "mydialogs.js" solves the problem completely.

I'm submitting this here in the hope that it will prove useful to the Browserify project. But I can't even guarantee 100% that the problem really comes from Browserify.

Thanks to anyone who will have a look.

title: downgrading browser-builtins
body:
The current version of `browser-builtins` [breaks multilevel](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/492).

Downgrading them to an earlier version fixes this issue.

title: browserify > 2.29 breaks multilevel
body:
More information about this issue is [here](https://github.com/juliangruber/multilevel/issues/38).

Between `2.29`  and `2.30` not too much happened and the major change is upgrading `browser-builtins`.
I remember also seeing something about `crypto` in one of the error messages - not sure though.

Hopefully we can resolve this asap with help of @juliangruber, @alexgorbatchev and @AndreasMadsen.

My current **workaround** is: `npm install -S browserify@2.29`

title: Pass name of globalRequire function and prelude
body:
through bundle to pack and browser-pack.
This allows configuration to support multiple
bundles that have their own unique require
function name for situations where you don't
know what other code you might be interacting
with on a page.

title: Stream data into Browserify?
body:
So, Browserify can stream data out, but can it accept streamed data?

Eg, i've got a stream that i want to pipe into Browserify. I would need to tell browserify where the CWD is for this stream data, but aside from that, i would think this would work.

With that said, i don't see any way to stream data into Browserify. Thoughts? I may fork it to add this functionality, because the idea of writing to a temporary file and loading Browserify.. from that file.. but still having a CWD of the source location.. it all just seems crazy.

Thoughts?

title: standalone of a entry with a expose property results in a broken .js file
body:
Adding a expose property to a standalone entry cases browserify to generate a broken .js file as it simple uses hash instead of a hash in braces at:

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L382

``` javascript
browserify()
  .require("./test.js", {expose: "myproject", entry: true})
  .bundle({standalone: 'myproject'})
```

title: License incompatibility, GPLv2 nested dependency
body:
This license incompatibility exists for any commercial/private use of browserify:

browserify (MIT)
--> browser-builtins (MIT)
--> buffer-browserify (MIT/X11)
--> base64-js (GPLv2)

We need to remove @beatgammit 's dependency from `buffer-browserify` unless he's willing to change the license. I'll open an issue in buffer-browserify as well.

title: Require Coffee Files without Coffee Extension?
body: Is there any way Browserify can require a coffee file (or any language you support via transforms) without requiring the extension? Eg, can you add extensions that will be resolved properly?

title: Can't even Require Browserify in Node v0.11.x?
body:
In the following code, i install browserify, import browserify, and immediately see an error.

```
leeolayvar@vm-0 ~/p/tmp> npm install --silent browserify                                                                                                                
browserify@2.31.0 node_modules/browserify
├── inherits@1.0.0

.2, buffer-browserify@0.2.2, punycode@1.2.3, http-browserify@0.1.12)

leeolayvar@vm-0 ~/p/tmp> cat foo.js

/home/leeolayvar/projects/tmp/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/umd/node_modules/uglify-js/lib/parse.js:53
```

title: Fix error when inserting globals and expose-ing
body:
I was experiencing an issue when trying to use [browserify-shim](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim) and [requireify](https://github.com/johnkpaul/requireify). Requireify requires --insert-globals to be set in order to get __filename access at runtime. When I tried to mesh the two together, I was getting this error:

```
path.js:313
        throw new TypeError('Arguments to path.resolve must be strings');
              ^
TypeError: Arguments to path.resolve must be strings
    at Object.exports.resolve (path.js:313:15)
    at Object.exports.relative (path.js:371:18)
    at Stream._vars.__filename (/Users/jpaul/workspace/browserify-shim/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/insert-module-globals/index.js:32:31)
```

I tracked this down to browserify not passing a row object with an `id` property to insert-globals when using `b.require(path, {expose:name});`. I've added that property to the output of .deps().

title: Loading order is wrong
parser crashes if the word require is used in a template
body: when using blissify (or any template middleware) it is possible to have the plaintext word `require` within the template. however, when running the bundler, browserify attempts to parse this (as a result of node-detective's AST walker) which throws a parse error.

title: Upgrade path for WISPs in tool
body: Need UX to begin with. I'm on it.

title: Support for node-webkit
body:
The following are suggestions.

The node-webkit project fuses NodeJS and webkit into a single runtime environment.

This makes it easy to require() modules intended for Node, which will (mostly) work. Sometimes though, you want to load modules into the browser "aspect" of node-webkit, and browserify is great for that. However, there are two problems:

1) browserify's require() hides the one provided by the NodeJS aspect of node-webkit.
(This can be worked around by simply putting all the node-dependent modules before the browserify-generated bundle)

2) browserify generates a "process" object that hides the one provided by the NodeJS aspect of node-webkit.
(This can be worked around as well, by assigning the original process object to a global variable.)

Even though work-arounds exist for both issues, I think it would be better if browserify could be told to a) provide its require() method under a different name and b) refrain from generating its own process object.

Other than that, thanks for providing a great tool!

title: Inserted chars in browserify build: Â
body:
In chrome when I open a browserify build of [LevelGraph](http://github.com/mcollina/levelgraph) done by the latest version of Browserify I get strange chars in it that are only showed in the browser but they are not in the original file.
You can see an example of the problem here:
https://cloudup.com/c0jThaIFwLB

It happens in different places of the source code.
Testling 1.5.1 (that bundles 2.29.1) works fine.

``` javascript
var data = require('./file.json')
```

This is already supported in node
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7163061/is-there-a-require-for-json-in-node-js

title: b.deps(opts) default options/transforms and docs
body: Tests seem to pass. Please review.

title: Update node-browser-builtins and update tests
body:
hi!

first of all: big thanks for your work, browserify is really awesome!

could you please update the dependecy to node-browser-builtins as soon as @alexgorbatchev published a new version https://github.com/alexgorbatchev/node-browser-builtins/issues/17 is closed? among others, the buffer implementation has an important bugfix.

thanks in advance!

title: module.require isn't present
body:
In node.js, `module.require` is the basis for the `require` function. Browserify instead directly hands the `require` function over, without exposing any functionality as `module.require`.

I'm trying to browserify a module that uses [defaultable](https://github.com/iriscouch/defaultable), which heavily depends on the behavior of node.

It would be awesome if `module.require` could be at least a reference to the `require` function.

title: Browserify standalone does not run in node when node global variable 'global' is present
body:
```
Exception loading: /Users/GT/work/sproutid/spec/sproutid/sproutid.spec.js
[ReferenceError: self is not defined]
```

This happens because `self` is not defined in nodejs.  Browserified file looks like:

```
(function(e){if("function"==typeof //...blah blah umd definition
return (function e(t,n,r){function s(o,u){if(!n[o]){//...blah blah included modules
var global=self;
```

`self` being undefined, it fails on line 3

I've found that a solution that looks like the following runs in the browser and node:

```
(function(e){if("function"==typeof //...blah blah umd definition
return (function e(t,n,r){function s(o,u){if(!n[o]){//...blah blah included modules
if("object" === typeof self && self) global = self; 
```

not sure if this is an issue for [node-browserify](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify) or [insert-module-globals](https://github.com/substack/insert-module-globals)

title: Allow arbitrary external ids
body:
Right now, ids used to reference modules in external bundles are
required to correspond to actual files, but it'd be helpful if these ids
could be arbitrary. This issue has been brought up in #387 and #472.

A small change to how external modules are loaded, combined with using
the mdeps filter option, allows for arbitrary external ids. This commit
includes test coverage.

title: external with target
body:
Hi,

I want to create 2 bundles, `public/vendor.js` and `public/site.js`.

```
browserify -r ./vendor/jquery.js:jquery > public/vendor.js
```

ok, jQuery is bundled as 'jquery', then:

```
browserify -x jquery src/site.js > public/site.js
Error: Cannot find module '/Users/abernier/Sites/browserifytest/jquery'
```

but yes, it's not a file but a "target" for a file...

Why rather than searching for the file, -x does not just ignore corresponding require() ?

title: Access to Node's require
added blissify, alpha sorted list of available transforms
bundle() callback is called twice (or more)
body: Because callback is called on `error` event then on multiple errors happened during single `bundle()` call callback will be called each time for different error. This breaks the semantics of callback.

title: "Buffer" conflict between insert-module-globals and browser-builtins?
body:
Troubleshooting this error: https://github.com/brianloveswords/zlib-browserify/issues/6

In the failed test, `buffer.parent !== buffer`. But in buffer-browserify, the only line that mentions `parent` is `this.parent = this`. Then I grepped and found a definition of `Buffer` in insert-module-globals. Then I noticed that in my browserified bundle, `Buffer` is defined twice.

title: Weird bug apply -> applyly
Provide example using the optional target syntax
body: Took a while for me to actually figure out how the optional target worked and thought it would be handy to provide an example in the readme.

title: sourcesContent is wrong when using --require
body:
When you do:

```
browserify -d -r ./jquery-2.0.3.js
```

The resulting source map's `sourcesContent` claims that the jquery file's original source is:

```
module.exports=require('SlcxIH');
```

title: Plugins
body:
Hi,

I don't recall whether I may have brought this up before (though I don't see it as an issue), so here goes...
1. What do you think about supporting a built-in plugin syntax for shims?

e.g.,

`require('shim!Array.prototype.forEach');`

I implemented a simple version as a transforming plugin at https://gist.github.com/brettz9/6149295 which as is transforms the above to:

`Array.prototype.forEach ? require('./Array.prototype.forEach') : '';`

..but it could be made to check for support of the method in Node, and clear the line entirely if not present (for when using the file in Node), etc.

Node.js may not need shims so frequently, but I like there to be a modular way to add global-creating shims no matter whether for use in the browser or Node. It can avoid polluting one's code with long shim hacks and can avoid preloading a module into memory (or potentially transferring its code over the wire) when the environment does not need the shim. One should not be held back, imo, from using convenient standard methods (with semantics well-known to other consumers of one's code) in one's modules because one (rightly) wishes to avoid including yet another copy of some large shim (which might also become of little need in the future).

Also, are you open to setting up a wiki here so people could list transforming plugins here? I also have one planned for transforming privileged browser requests (for https://github.com/brettz9/asyouwish/ ) into regular Node.js require statements when used in Node and AsYouWish.requestPrivs() statements to have one's website ask the Firefox Addons SDK for higher privileges.

Brett

title: Update umd
body: This merges in a few small fixes where I'd misunderstood the code I was copying (thanks to @domenic for fixing).  It also adds unit tests.

title: Allow browser users to use their own dependencies
body:
I'm implementing browserify in a plugin for a popular open source library. Currently it works both in the browser and node via an `npm install` and we'd like to keep it that way. It's only dependencies are `Bacon.js` (the library we're plugging into) and jQuery. I'm installing those currently via bower, because I was getting errors with the NPM jQuery (another issue for another time, fine with bower for now).

We **do not** want the bundle to include Bacon or jQuery; instead users can choose whatever compatible version they want to use of each, via whatever package manager they want. We're fine with depending on the browser-global versions of these packages, but we'd still like to use `require("Bacon")` and `require("jQuery")` in development.

I've tried using external but the bundle tries to require("5PF18U"), guessing some hashed version of a dependency, expecting to have that included in another bundle. I've also tried using ignore and shim, but that just seems to pull the dependencies into the bundle anyway.

Here's a link that shows [the configurations I've tried and the wrapped output of my bundle](https://gist.github.com/joefiorini/1c844b455bee9b6a35f8). What is the correct combination of options to make this incantation work?

title: Export a require that translate require('d3') -> window.d3
body: Is it possible to reference `window.d3` while still keeping `var d3 = require('d3')` in my module code? When I'm within my own walled garden it's fine, but posting demo code like: http://bl.ocks.org/dalejung/raw/6077321/ requires me to uploaded the d3 lib as part of the bundle.

title: add support for Browserify.external(bundle)
body:
Allows for one bundle to reference another bundle for any requires which
the external bundle may contain. Allows for better reuse of dependencies
to avoid duplication when packaging for client.

title: feature chem in the readme under 3rd party tools?
body:
[chem](https://github.com/superjoe30/chem/) is a game engine optimized for rapid development.

It uses browserify for packaging user code together.

I feel like it's a pretty good example of how browserify can be effectively utilized.

title: Support for lazy evaluation.
Can the standalone option save a namespaced global variable?
body:
From how I read the code, I don't believe it can, but I'm curious if I'm missing something. If I'm not, I think it would be a nice feature.

For example, if a user of my library is including a few of my sub-modules and doesn't have AMD support, it would be nice to have all of those sub-modules namespaced into a common global, e.g. `window.myLib`:

```
browserify src/ui/alert.js -s "myLib.ui.Alert" -o dist/ui/alert.js
browserify src/ui/dowdown.js -s "myLib.ui.Dropdown" -o dist/ui/dowdown.js
```

p.s. I'm new to browserify so pardon this question if it doesn't make sense within browserify's intended scope.

title: Use transforms with --deps and --list flags.
body: Unless the source transforms are included when using `--list` or `--deps`, some builds will fail with a syntax error - e.g. when using brfs. Simple fix :)

title: Replace fs module (or any browser-builtin-provided module)
body:
Package.json:

``` json
{
  "browser": {
    "./inc.js": "./onc.js"
  }
}
```

index.js:

``` javascript
require("./inc.js")
```

`browserify index.js > bundle.js` then works as expected: inc.js is replaced by onc.js.

Then I changed `./inc.js` in both package.json and index.js to `fs`. I then expected `browserify index.js > bundle.js` to work like before: fs should be replaced by onc.js. But that's not the case. Instead I get the [useless, empty fs replacement](https://github.com/alexgorbatchev/node-browser-builtins/blob/master/builtin/fs.js) from [browser-builtins](https://github.com/alexgorbatchev/node-browser-builtins).

In a project I want to replace the fs module with my own for the browser, that provides `fs.readFileSync()` by using a sync `XMLHttpRequest`. (I cannot use [brfs](https://github.com/substack/brfs) since the files are not known beforehand.)

This seems to be true for any of the browser-builtin-provided modules.

title: -x Doesn't works
body:
I cant build A.js file that requires B.js. Without having B.js.

**A.js**

``` javascript
var B = require('B');
var A = B;
module.exports = B;
```

Requirement of 'B' must be resolved in run-time.
I'll tried to compile it with

``` bash
browserify -x B A.js
```

But it cause an error

``` bash
Error: module "B" not found in require()
```

Is it right behavior?
How can i compile 'A' without 'B' at compile time.
`--im` has no affect too.

title: `transform` is singular
body: If you follow the README and make it plural, your app won't build.

title: Octal literals are not allowed in strict mode
